title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.001
frontText: What is data temperature and why is it important?
backText: Data is tiered into hot, warm, and cold storage. Typically, data is characterized into hot, warm, and cold based on the frequency at which it is accessed, updated, and maintained. For example, with telecom data, the last 6 months of call detail records may be categorized as hot, data over 6 months but under 12 months as warm, and data older than 12 months as cold data. This is important because it helps identify the value of the data and the right storage technology for such data.

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.002
frontText: What are the three major types of data that are collected/ingested into an analytics pipeline?
backText: There are three major data source types: transactions, files, and events.

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.003
frontText: What stream storage options are provided on the AWS platform?
backText: AWS offers two stream storage options: Kafka (Apache Kafka on EC2 instances and Managed Streaming for Kafka) and Amazon Kinesis (Amazon Kinesis Data Streams and Amazon Kinesis Firehose).

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.004
frontText: What is a benefit of streaming storage?
backText: Streaming storage allows you to decouple your producers from your consumers.

frontText: Name some of the benefits of S3 storage that make S3 a key choice for your data and analytics pipeline storage and a landing zone for all of your data?
backText: S3 provides the following benefits, which makes it a de facto storage engine for your analytics pipeline:

backText: For the warm and hot data, Amazon supports various options, which fall into three major categories:

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.010
frontText: What are key architectural principles for your data lake?
backText: Decouple your data bus: data ˃ storage ˃ processing ˃ analysis ˃ answers.

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.011
frontText: What are two types of data processing?
backText: Batch processing – Support finite amounts of data. Examples are jobs scheduled on an hourly or a nightly basis.

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.012
frontText: When is stream processing an ideal choice for data processing?
backText: Stream processing is an ideal choice in cases where latency to ingest, store, and process the data is of utmost importance and needs to be as low as possible, sometimes in single‐digit milliseconds.

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.013
frontText: What technologies are available on the AWS platform to handle streaming data?

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.014
frontText: What is Amazon Kinesis’s pricing model?
backText: Amazon Kinesis is priced on a pay‐as‐you‐go model based on shard hour and PUT payload limits.

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.015
frontText: What is a Kinesis shard?
backText: A shard is a uniquely identified sequence of streams and provides fixed capacity. You can consider shards as partitioning of your data inside a stream. Each shard can support up to five read transactions per second up to a total of 2 MB of data read per second. Each shard can support up to 1000 write transactions per second up to a maximum of 1 MB of data written per second.

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.016
frontText: How can you write data to a Kinesis stream?

frontText: What is KPL?
backText: KPL stands for Kinesis producer library, a library designed to enable applications (aka producers) to write data to Kinesis streams, which simplifies the entire process of writing data to a stream and achieve better throughput. Key benefits of KPL are as follows:

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.019
frontText: What is HCatalog?
backText: Allows you to access Hive metastore tables in a variety of applications. Examples are Pig, Hive, SparkSQL and other MapReduce applications. Glue Metastore is compatible with Hive metastore.

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.023
frontText: True or False: Amazon Kinesis Firehose streams data directly to Redshift?
backText: False – When the destination for Amazon Kinesis Firehose is Redshift, data is delivered to an S3 bucket and then a “copy” command is issued to copy the data from the S3 bucket to Amazon Redshift.

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.028
frontText: Using a lambda function in your Kinesis application can be useful in the following scenarios:
backText:
1. Transforming records from other formats (such as KPL or GZIP) into formats that Kinesis Data Analytics can analyze. Kinesis Data Analytics currently supports JSON or CSV data formats.
  2. Expanding data into a format that is more accessible for operations such as aggregation or anomaly detection. For instance, if several data values are stored together in a string, you can expand the data into separate columns.
  3. Data enrichment with other AWS services, such as extrapolation or error correction.
  4. Applying complex string transformation to record fields.
  5. Data filtering for cleaning up the data.

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.029
frontText: What machine learning algorithms are available with Amazon Kinesis Data Analytics?

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.030
frontText: What is a KPU?
backText: A KPU is a Kinesis processing unit, which is a unit of stream processing capacity comprising 1 vCPU compute and 4 GB memory. Amazon Kinesis Data Analytics automatically scales the number of KPUs required for your stream processing application based on the demands from the application code.

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.031
frontText: What is Apache Flink?
backText: Apache Flink is a top‐level Apache project, which has a simple programming model and makes it easier to build streaming applications using the flexible APIs. It provides low latency and high throughput with its in‐memory computing and provides stateful processing and exactly‐once semantics.

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.032
frontText: What is Amazon Kinesis Video Streams?
backText: Amazon Kinesis Video Streams is a fully managed service, that is scalable and allows you to stream videos from millions of sources, including smart phones, security cameras, web cams, drones, cameras embedded in cars, and other sources. You can also send non‐video time‐serialized data such as audio data, thermal imagery, depth data, and RADAR data.

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.033
frontText: What are the key benefits of Amazon Kinesis Video Streams?
backText: The key benefits of Kinesis video streams for a customer are as follows:

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.034
frontText: What is AWS Glue?
backText: AWS Glue is a fully managed ETL (Extraction, Transformation and Loading) service that allows you to extract the data and metadata from various sources like databases and build a catalog of information that can then be used to transform the data to your target required state.

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.035
frontText: What is a classifier?
backText: A classifier is a piece of code that classifies the source data into numbers, strings, phone numbers, social security numbers, and addresses using a number of rules. AWS Glue also offers built‐in and custom classifiers that can be used to classify data.

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.036
frontText: What is a crawler?
backText: A crawler is a program that connects to a data store (source or target), progresses through a prioritized list of classifiers to determine the schema for your data, and then creates metadata in the AWS Glue Data Catalog. AWS Glue crawlers can scan, classify, and extract schema information and then store the metadata automatically in the AWS Glue Data Catalog. The metadata is stored in the form of tables. Crawlers can also detect schema changes and version the tables for previously crawled data stores and detect hive‐style partitions on Amazon S3. For previously crawled Amazon S3 partitioned data, the crawler will add new partitions or update the changed partitions by default. Crawlers run on demand or on a schedule to suit your needs.

backText: AWS glue offers the following transformations as part of the UI:

frontText: What are the benefits of Amazon SQS?

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.044
frontText: What is AWS DMS?
backText: AWS DMS (Data Migration Service) is a cloud‐based service that takes the pain away from migrating relational data between a number of supported databases and filesystems.

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.047
frontText: What is AWS Data Pipeline?
backText: AWS Data Pipeline is a web service that allows you to orchestrate workflows and automate the movement and transformation of the data.

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.048
frontText: AWS Data Pipeline can use _____________ to run a Pig script on Amazon EMR.

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.049
frontText: AWS Data pipeline offers the following pre‐packaged activities for common data processing scenarios:
backText:
• CopyActivity – Copy data from one location to another
  • EmrActivity – Run an Amazon EMR cluster.
  • HiveActivity – Run a hive query on an Amazon EMR cluster.
  • HiveCopyActivity – Run a Hive query on an Amazon EMR. cluster with support for advanced filtering and support for S3 data node.
  • PigActivity – Run a Pig script on an Amazon EMR cluster.
  • RedshiftCopyActivity – Copy data to and from Amazon Redshift tables.
  • ShellCommandActivity – Run a custom Unix/Linux shell command activity.
  • SqlActivity – Run an SQL query on a database.

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.051
frontText: What is a bucket in Amazon S3?
backText: A bucket is a container of objects in Amazon S3, and no object can exist without an Amazon S3 bucket. Buckets help organize the Amazon S3 namespace at the highest level with each bucket having an associated storage and retrieval cost. Buckets help you define appropriate access control to different data within your organization.

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.056
frontText: How can Amazon S3 replicate data?
backText: Amazon S3 can automatically replicate data from one bucket to another in the same account or to a different account. You can also copy objects within the same AWS Region using (SRR, or same‐region replication) or to a different AWS Region using (CRR, or cross‐region replication). Replication can be done as follows:

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.061
frontText: What is Amazon Glacier and what is it used for?
backText: Amazon Glacier is a low‐cost object storage service to store data in a secure and durable manner. The typical use cases for Amazon Glacier are data archiving and data backups

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.062
frontText: What is Amazon DynamoDB?
backText: Amazon DynamoDB is a fully managed NoSQL database service running in the AWS cloud. DynamoDB allows you to focus on your business logic while managing the complexity of running and managing a NoSQL database running at extremely large scale. The service is offered on a pay‐as‐you‐go model. It is extremely efficient for applications requiring low single‐digit millisecond latency.

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.063
frontText: What are the data types of Amazon DynamoDB?
backText: Amazon DynamoDB offers three categories of data types Scalar, Document and Set:

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.064
frontText: What is the use of partition keys and sort keys in DynamoDB?
backText: Partition and sort keys are important elements from a performance standpoint. Partition keys are used to identify the actual storage location for the data and help in fast retrieval as well when used during data access. Sort keys provide an additional indexing mechanism by sorting the data in the order defined by sort key.

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.065
frontText: Amazon DynamoDB is a ________________ service.

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.066
frontText: True or false? A customer table in US East (North Virginia) and US West(North California) for AccountNumber 888888888888 is the same table.
backText: False. Since DynamoDB is a regional service, tables in each region are identified as a separate tables.

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.067
frontText: What are the two consistency models offered for reads by Amazon DynamoDB?
backText: Amazon DynamoDB offers two consistency models.

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.068
frontText: What are DynamoDB global tables?
backText: A mechanism by which you can build a fully managed multi‐Region and multi‐master database without having to build your own replication solution. When you build a global table, you specify the AWS Regions where you want the table to be available, and Amazon DynamoDB manages the complexity of creating identical tables in the chosen regions and then replicates data among them.

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.069
frontText: What are the two types of primary keys supported by DynamoDB?
backText: A partition key and a composite (partition key and sort key)

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.070
frontText: What types of secondary indexes are offered by DynamoDB?
backText: Local secondary index (LSI) ‐ An LSI is an index that has the same partition key as the base table but a different sort key. The total size of indexed items for any one partition key value can’t exceed 10 GB. You can define up to five LSIs per table.

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.071
frontText: What are the read/write capacity modes for DynamoDB?

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.072
frontText: On‐demand: As the name indicates, is a flexible option provided by DynamoDB that adjusts your capacity per the demands of your workloads and scales them up and down.
backText: You create new tables with unknown workloads.

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.073
frontText: Provisioned mode means you can specify the number of reads and writes per second required for your application. This is also flexible as you can use auto‐scaling to scale up and down the provisioned resources based on your workload demands.

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.074
frontText: What are DynamoDB WCU and RCU?
backText: WCU stands for write capacity unit for DynamoDB. One write capacity unit represents one write per second for an item up to 1 KB in size. If you need to write an item larger than 1 KB in size, DynamoDB will consume additional WCU.

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.075

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.109
frontText: What is EMRFS?
backText: EMRFS is an implementation of HDFS used by Amazon EMR to read/write data from/to Amazon S3. EMRFS provides consistent views, which provides consistency checks for read‐after‐write for objects in Amazon S3.

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.110
frontText: How does EMRFS use DynamoDB?
backText: EMRFS uses DynamoDB as a file registry for EMRFS consistent views.

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.111
frontText: How can you install additional custom software on an EMR cluster before Hadoop software starts?
backText: EMR uses bootstrap actions, which can be executed on a Hadoop cluster before Hadoop daemons start up on each node. You can have up to 16 bootstrap actions.

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.134

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.145
frontText: When is the interleaved sort key beneficial?
backText: Each column in the sort key is sorted with equal weighting. This is useful when multiple queries use different access paths and different columns for filters and joins. This should be used with caution and in edge cases only.

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.147
frontText: What are best practices for Data Lake and Redshift?
backText: Number of files in the data lake should be a multiple of your Redshift slice count (general best practice). Redshift Lakehouse can automatically split Parquet, ORC, text-format, and Bz2 files for optimal processing.

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.151
frontText: What are Redshift data loading best practices?
backText: Use COPY command to load data whenever possible.

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.152
frontText: What are the types of network transmissions for data in Redshift?
backText: DS_DIST_NONE – This is the ideal situation that indicates that the data for the join is co-located on the same slice; this is the most efficient option as no network transfer will occur.

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.153
frontText: How can you enable SSO with Redshift?
backText: You can configure a SAML 2.0 compliant identity provider to permit your federated users access to a role. The role can then be used to get temporary credentials to log in to Redshift.

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.154
frontText: What are the types of windows supported in Kinesis Data Analytics?
backText: Staggered windows – Useful for data arriving at inconsistent times.

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.155
frontText: When should you use AWS Glue vs. Amazon EMR?
backText: AWS Glue is a fully managed serverless ETL service offering managed Apache Spark and Python Shell.

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.174
frontText: What are best practices for security on Amazon S3
backText:
1. Enable account‐level Block Public Access.
  2. Leverage access points to scope application permissions.
  3. Send secure traffic with VPC endpoints and access points.
  4. Use bucket policy to enforce TLS.
  5. Encrypt everything: SSE‐KMS &SSE‐S3.
  6. Enable Object Lock, Versioning, MFA delete to protect data.
  7. Monitor using AWS tools, such as AWS CloudTrail and AWSConfig.

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.175
frontText: Amazon Redshift logs information in the following log files:
backText: Connection log – This log file logs all connection attempts, connections, and disconnections. This log is primarily for security purposes.

title: fc649472.AWSCDASG.178
frontText: What are Amazon Kinesis best practices for security?
backText:
1. Create an IAM entity for Admin actions. For example, CreateStream, DeleteStream, AddTagsToStream, and RemoveTagsFromStream.
  2. Create an IAM entity for re‐sharding of a stream. For example, MergeShards and SplitShard.
  3. Create an IAM entity for producers to writes. For example, DescribeStream, PutRecord, and PutRecords.
  4. Use temporary security credentials (IAM roles) instead of long‐term access keys wherever appropriate.
  5. If data encryption is required in flight, perform client‐side encryption before sending to Amazon Kinesis.
  6. Allow producers/consumers based on their expected user agent and source IP addresses.
  7. Enforce use of the aws:SecureTransport condition key for every API call made to AWS.
